body: Modulo the four clarifications/requests I made today, this looks ready to merge.
I have reviewed the pull requests and tried it myself. I find the ansible commands much more verbose and expect we will want to sugar these to get back to the simplicity of `ant clean build deploy`.
Closing will deliver on #443

@rabbah regarding syntax sugar: we can make a specific env the default. for example "local". in which case all you need to run is:

```
ansible-playbook openwhisk.yml
```

to deploy

@sjfink could you also update line https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/docker.gradle#L12

"\* - dockerTimeout (optional, default 240): Timeout for docker operations in seconds"

@syntiux  I hit this in my PR #360 
 Fix is to modify all.sh

```
#!/bin/bash
SOURCE="${BASH_SOURCE[0]}"
SCRIPTDIR="$( dirname "$SOURCE" )"
```

@syntiux, yes, I'll sumbit a fix.
@csantanapr , thank you.
@syntiux ,I didn't test the scenario with Vagrant up, sorry for this trouble.

@eljuanchosf I think I met with the same issue with you. I'm running my OpenWhisk in a CouchDB installed in the same server. couchdb-local.env is configured as following:

OPEN_WHISK_DB_PROTOCOL=https
OPEN_WHISK_DB_HOST=127.0.0.1
OPEN_WHISK_DB_PORT=6984
OPEN_WHISK_DB_USERNAME=root
OPEN_WHISK_DB_PASSWORD=ps

Can you explain more detail about "The problem was with the name of the database host" and how to "workaround" ?

Daisy

Hi @daisy-ycguo 

The problem @eljuanchosf faced was using a non-ephemeral, non-docker couchdb running natively on his system. He tried to use `localhost` to reach that database but `localhost` in a container is not your local machine but the container itself.

Does that match your local deployment?

A possible workaround is to use the IP of your machine as DB_HOST instead of `localhost` or aliases like `127.0.0.1`.
merged in 92887bbf9763f3d4204d15ee53d13600d375ef08

Hi, @eljuanchosf 

Yes, it matched. You can see from my couchdb-local.env, I want to reach my database using https://127.0.0.1:6984, not _localhost_. I think it's exactly the same situation with @eljuanchosf .

I'm sure my local CouchDB runs well. It can be reached both by https://127.0.0.1:6984 and http://127.0.0.1:5984. I tested by "curl -k https://127.0.0.1:6984" and "curl -k http://127.0.0.1:5984".
I'm even quite sure the whisk.system is stored in the database. I can query the data by: curl -s -k --user root:ps -X GET https://127.0.0.1:6984/subjects/whisk.system.

I tried to config _https_ and 6984 in couchdb-local.env, it reported the same error as @eljuanchosf reported when "ant deploy". Then I tried to config _http_ and 5984 in couchdb-local.env, it reported the same error: The supplied authentication is invalid.

It's quite interesting because ./tools/db/createImmortalDBs.sh can successfully insert data to CouchDB, but it looks like wsk cannot. I'm quite curious how @eljuanchosf work it around.

Daisy
Oh. I understand. I should use the exact IP address, not IP address: 127.0.0.1 to access CouchDB. Let me try if it works. Thank you, @markusthoemmes

Yeah, it works. 
I changed the IP address in couchdb-local.env to the real IP address, not _127.0.0.1_, "ant deploy" runs well. Thank you for the help, @markusthoemmes

tz mount is no longer used with ansible deployments. so closing this as obsolete since we want to move away from ant anyway. we can open a new issue, should we run into any tz difficulties on ansible.

Travis failing only on a swift3 test which is known to have intermittent issues and being looked investigated.  Rebasing and re-running travis.

Hum right now, I think we keep the short memory to the user to only "to set any configuration for the cli itself only need to remember one spot to do it" `wsk property`

Also `wsk namespace set ...` feels wrong as user would think they are changing something on the namespace itself on the backend (permanent), and not a setting of the current installation of the cli`

Switching the current/default namespace that cli commands will use feels more a global config for the current install of cli, and I think it's more proper `wsk property set` 

At the same time I'm not too in love of the "set" and "get" terminology, maybe because of my past work on mfpdev-cli :smile:

We had global context and local context, and used the term `config` it matches 'git' and 'npm' these were kind of tools we follow pattern:

`mfpdev app config <key> <value>` (sets a config key for the app context)
`mfpdev app config <key>` (prints/gets the value for config key)
`mfpdev app config --list` (prints all the available keys with corresponding human description to get or set)
`mfpdev config <key> <value>` (sets a global configuration key for the CLI, value affects all commands)

We could have:
`wsk config ...` for cli settings
`wsk config namespace <new_namespace>` switch to new namespace for cli commands
`wsk list --namespaces` (lists all namespaces available)

I think #441 is a duplicate.  Basically, moving dockerSkeleton to open involves actually moving the directory over and making adjustments to the following:
1. Build process (scripts and directory) which used to be in ant but now is in gradle
2. One test that downloads the skeleton may need adjustment
3. The CLI will have to be adjusted based on details from step 1

Rebased and merged as [405efb4](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/405efb4acec0f3bd7c1878117c12b9ee228d2ef4).

i think the challenge is -- when using `wsk property set`, users won't know the syntax to use, so at a minimum the cli help for that command needs to be enhanced. i tend to like the `wsk namespace <verb>` syntax better, since it seems more direct to the user ('i want to change the namespace, so let me look at the sub-commands for `wsk namespace`). if there are concerns regarding the selection of the verb (`set` vs. something else), we can look at alternative proposals. which verbs would you feel better with?
@rabbah requested that I use whisk.done for the error. @rabbah plans to deliver a fix for whisk.done to properly handle the json object and then merge this pull request.

I struggled to understand the event, trigger, feed dichotomy until I implemented my own feed. 
As a developer, I associate "feed" with passive data sources, an RSS feed. 
Looking through the catalogue packages, I discovered the a "feed" is closer to a service broker. It receives lifecycle events for registered triggers, which it can register with an external provider.

This is not a lot of work to support with spray. There is an `option` [directive](http://spray.io/documentation/1.2.3/spray-routing/method-directives/options/) already and the implementation of a CORS trait/directive shouldn't be more than `30` lines. With tests, `< 100` lines.

You're right to point this out. It exists on triggers and rules as well but is currently not used/enforced. The only effect this flag has, when applied to packages is to share or hide the contents of the package, entirely.

The only way to blanket share resources is via a public package. We should remove from the CLI --shared support on all other entities with the exception of packages. The API will require a small adjustment as well to compute the `public` property correctly based on package visibility.

This is related to #471. `wsk trigger delete` doesn't permit parameters which would be useful in this case for deleting a feed. As a work around, you can run the feed directly. Did you try that?

A trigger update does not run a feed - only the trigger create does.

What is the correct behavior for trigger update when tied to a feed?

I would expect it to DELETE and CREATE the feed.    Comments?

As update doesn't execute the feed, how it can be helpful ? 

**what I have done :**

```
$ wsk trigger create RTIFeed --feed /namespace/iotrti/webh -p condition 'schema.value>1' 
ok: created trigger feed RTIFeed

$ wsk activation list
a11c18d9eae148179160b91c9d4ec455             webh

$ wsk trigger update RTIFeed -p condition 'schema.value>2'
ok: updated trigger RTIFeed

$ wsk activation list
a11c18d9eae148179160b91c9d4ec455             webh
```

from the activation list, the feed has not been executed when I used the update command !

@csantanapr is there bluemix-docs pr?

Note 2 is particularly important as the occasional slowness of consul as well as our data set growing can lead to constant banging on consul which can make things worse.  Since we are refactoring all of this now, we might as well do it.  The original Thread version with inter-iteration sleep prevents this from happening because it would start the next iteration 5 seconds after the prior iteration completes.  The new version will schedule an iteration every 5 seconds regardless of how long a prior iteration took.

Separately, note that we are hitting consul unnecessarily because the loadbalancer piece of the info is locally available.  However, we can probably defer fixing this to another PR as it's not worse than it already is.
